It will be appreciated that some individual polymer molecules in the concentrate may have no functional substituents thereon, and that some individual polymer molecules in the concentrate may have 2, 3, 4, 5, or more functional substituents thereon.
These polymers generally are random copolymers of substituted and unsubstituted siloxane repeat units, although alternating, graft, and block copolymers are also suitable.
In one preferred embodiment, R1, R2, R3, R4, R5, R6, R7, R8, and R9 are all methyl groups. T-Type amino-substituted organosiloxane polymers are also suitable.

The amino-substituted or mercapto-substituted organosiloxane polymer is of any suitable or desired effective weight average molecular weight, typically from about 4,000 to about 20,000, and preferably from about 12,000 to about 18,000, although the weight average molecular weight can be outside of these ranges.

The amino-substituted or mercapto-substituted organosiloxane polymer generally has a viscosity at about 25 (degree) C. of from about 50 to about 500 centistokes, and preferably from about 300 to about 400 centistokes, although the viscosity can be outside of these ranges.

The diluent comprising the nonfunctional organosiloxane polymer and the concentrate comprising the amino-substituted or mercapto-substituted organosiloxane polymer are generally present in the mixture of the present invention in relative amounts by weight of from about 1 part concentrate per about 2 parts diluent to about 1 part concentrate per about 30 parts diluent, and preferably from about 1 part concentrate per about 3 parts diluent to about 1 part concentrate per about 10 parts diluent, although the relative amounts of these components can be outside of these ranges.

The resulting mixture typically has a viscosity at about 25 (degree) C. of from about 100 to about 1,000 centistokes, and preferably from about 400 to about 800 centistokes, although the viscosity can be outside of these ranges.

In the mixture of the present invention, the mole percent of amino or mercapto substituents typically is from about 0.05 to about 0.4 percent.
In one specific embodiment of the present invention, in the mixture, the mole percent of amino substituents typically is from about 0.05 to about 0.2 mole percent, and preferably from about 0.06 to about 0.12 percent, i.e., the value of (Equation image '3' not included in text)

typically is from about 0.0005 to about 0.002, and preferably is from about 0.0006 to about 0.0012, although the mole percentage of amino functional groups can be outside of these ranges.
In another specific embodiment of the present invention, in the mixture, the mole percent of mercapto substituents typically is from about 0.1 to about 0.4 mole percent, and preferably from about 0.15 to about 0.3 percent, i.e., the value of (Equation image '4' not included in text)

typically is from about 0.001 to about 0.004, and preferably is from about 0,0015 to about 0.003, although the mole percentage of mercapto functional groups can be outside of these ranges.
These numbers represent the amount of functional groups present in the mixture of concentrate and diluent relative to the number of organosiloxane (--SiR2 --) groups present in the mixture.
It will be appreciated that some individual polymer molecules in the mixture may have no functional substituents thereon, and that some individual polymer molecules in the mixture may have 2, 3, 4, 5, or more functional substituents thereon.

The release agents comprising the mixture of concentrate and diluent of the present invention remain functionally fluid at temperatures typically of up to about 500 (degree) F., and preferably from about 30 to about 450 (degree) F., although the temperatures at which the release agents are functionally fluid can be outside of this range.

Preferably, the release agent forms a continuous film on the polymer surface of the fuser member.
The silicone oils of the present invention typically are supplied in an amount of from about 0.1 to about 20 microliters per copy, preferably from about 2 to about 15 microliters per copy, and more preferably from about 5 to about 12 microliters per copy, although the amount can be outside of these ranges.

Amino-substituted organosiloxane polymers having a viscosity of about 350 centistokes at about 25 (degree) C. and an amine concentration of about 0.15 mole percent, when coated onto fluoropolymers commonly used as fuser member outer layers and used to fuse electrostatic toner images to print substrates such as paper, typically exhibit disadvantages such as poor adhesion of 3M Post-It.RTM. notes, poor ink adhesion to the surface of the paper subsequent to fusing, poor fix of inks such as bank check endorser inks and other similar inks to the fused paper, and the like.
When amino-substituted organosiloxane polymers having a viscosity of about 100 centistokes at about 25 (degree) C. and an amine concentration of about 0.15 mole percent are employed under similar conditions, the adhesion of Post-It.RTM. notes to the resulting prints is substantially improved.
The release life of the fuser member, however, is significantly decreased when used in conjunction with the 100 centistoke viscosity release agent.
When a mixture of concentrate containing an amino-substituted organosiloxane polymer having a viscosity of from about 50 to about 500 centistokes at about 25 (degree) C. and an amine concentration of from about 0.2 to about 2 mole percent is admixed with a nonfunctional organosiloxane polymer having a viscosity of from about 100 to about 2,000 centistokes at about 25 (degree) C., the resulting mixture, which generally has a viscosity of from about 100 to about 1,000 centistokes at about 25 (degree) C. and an amine concentration of from about 0.05 to about 0.2 mole percent, improved adhesion of Post-It.RTM. notes to the prints is observed, and release life of the fuser is also desirably high.

While not being limited to any particular theory, it is believed that lower viscosity fusing oils diffuse into paper faster than higher viscosity fusing oils of the same composition, all conditions being equal, and that functional fusing oils diffuse into paper more slowly than nonfunctional fusing oils of the same composition, all conditions being equal; in the instant invention, it is believed that the diluent portion of the mixture, i.e., the high viscosity nonfunctional oil, diffuses into paper faster than the concentrate portion of the mixture, i.e., the low viscosity amino or mercapto functional oil.
Accordingly, any low viscosity functional fusing agent molecules chemisorbed onto the paper surface provide insufficient coverage to impair the adhesion of Post-It.RTM. notes to the prints, since the low viscosity amino-substituted polymer diffuses into the paper faster than would a similar functional fusing oil of high viscosity.
Again, while not being limited to any particular theory, it is believed that the increased release life observed with the mixtures of the present invention, compared to a similar blend containing a low viscosity concentrate and a low viscosity diluent, results from improved hydrodynamics of the fusing agent metering system (such as a donor roll or the like).
More specifically, it is believed that when one or more dust particles, toner particles, paper particles, or the like are trapped under a metering blade, the fusing agent level in that region of the fuser member is depleted when a low viscosity fusing agent is employed; the depleted fusing agent level on the fuser member promotes toner offset, which can be invisible initially, but will later accelerate to visible offset.
Specific offset observed with the low viscosity fusing release agent generally begins as a fine streak less than one millimeter in width, and then grows in width as more streaks appear.
In contrast, with the mixtures making up the fusing release agents of the present invention, the level of fusing agent on the fuser member is substantially more uniform, and offset is not observed until many more copies have been made, said offset appearing as a spot.

The present invention is also directed to a process which comprises (i) generating an electrostatic latent image on an imaging member; (ii) developing the latent image by contacting the imaging member with a developer; (iii) transferring the developed image to a copy substrate; and (iv) affixing the developed image to the copy substrate by contacting the developed image with a fuser member comprising a substrate, a layer thereover comprising a polymer, and, on the polymeric layer, a coating of a release agent comprising a mixture of (a) an organosiloxane polymer concentrate containing amino-substituted or mercapto-substituted organosiloxane polymers, wherein there are amino or mercapto functional groups on at least some of the polymer molecules of the concentrate, said concentrate having a degree of functionality of from about 0.2 to about 2 mole percent, said concentrate having a viscosity of from about 50 to about 500 centistokes; and (b) a nonfunctional organosiloxane polymer diluent, said diluent having a viscosity of from about 100 to about 2,000 centistokes; said mixture having a degree of functionality of from about 0.05 to about 0.21 mole percent, wherein the mixture has a viscosity of from about 100 to about 1,000 centistokes, and wherein the ratio by weight of concentrate to diluent is from about 1:2 to about 1:30.
Examples of suitable substrates include (but are not limited to) plain papers such as Xerox.RTM. 4024 papers, ruled notebook paper, bond paper, silica coated papers such as Sharp Company silica coated paper, Jujo paper, and the like, transparency materials, fabrics, textile products, plastics, polymeric films, inorganic substrates such as metals and wood, and the like.

The present invention also encompasses an image forming apparatus for forming images on a recording medium which comprises: (i) a charge-retentive surface capable of receiving an electrostatic latent image thereon; (ii) a development assembly to apply toner to the charge-retentive surface, thereby developing the electrostatic latent image to form a developed image on the charge retentive surface; (iii) a transfer assembly to transfer the developed image from the charge retentive surface to a copy substrate; and (iv) a fixing assembly to fuse toner images to a surface of the copy substrate, wherein the fixing assembly includes a fuser member comprising a substrate, a layer thereover comprising a polymer, and, on the polymeric layer, a coating of a release agent comprising a mixture of (a) an organosiloxane polymer concentrate containing amino-substituted or mercapto-substituted organosiloxane polymers, wherein there are amino or mercapto functional groups on at least some of the polymer molecules of the concentrate, said concentrate having a degree of functionality of from about 0.2 to about 2 mole percent, said concentrate having a viscosity of from about 50 to about 500 centistokes; and (b) a nonfunctional organosiloxane polymer diluent, said diluent having a viscosity of from about 100 to about 2,000 centistokes; said mixture having a degree of functionality of from about 0.05 to about 0.21 mole percent, wherein the mixture has a viscosity of from about 100 to about 1,000 centistokes, and wherein the ratio by weight of concentrate to diluent is from about 1:2 to about 1:30.

An additional embodiment of the present invention is directed to a process for improving adhesion to a fused print substrate and for improving fuser oil release life which comprises (i) generating an electrostatic latent image on an imaging member, (ii) developing the latent image by contacting the imaging member with a developer; (iii) transferring the developed image to a copy substrate; and (iv) affixing the developed image to the copy substrate by contacting the developed image with a fuser member comprising a substrate, a layer thereover comprising a polymer, and, on the polymeric layer, a coating of a release agent comprising a mixture of (a) an organosiloxane polymer concentrate containing amino-substituted or mercapto-substituted organosiloxane polymers, wherein there are amino or mercapto functional groups on at least some of the polymer molecules of the concentrate, said concentrate having a degree of functionality of from about 0.2 to about 2 mole percent, said concentrate having a viscosity of from about 50 to about 500 centistokes; and (b) a nonfunctional organosiloxane polymer diluent, said diluent having a viscosity of from about 100 to about 2,000 centistokes; said mixture having a degree of functionality of from about 0.05 to about 0.21 mole percent, wherein the mixture has a viscosity of from about 100 to about 1,000 centistokes, and wherein the ratio by weight of concentrate to diluent is from about 1:2 to about 1:30.

A further embodiment of the present invention is directed to a process for simultaneously obtaining acceptable to a fused print substrate and obtaining acceptable fuser oil release life which comprises (i) generating an electrostatic latent image on an imaging member; (ii) developing the latent image by contacting the imaging member with a developer; (iii) transferring the developed image to a copy substrate; and (iv) affixing the developed image to the copy substrate by contacting the developed image with a fuser member comprising a substrate, a layer thereover comprising a polymer, and, on the polymeric layer, a coating of a release agent comprising a mixture of (a) an organosiloxane polymer concentrate containing amino-substituted or mercapto-substituted organosiloxane polymers, wherein there are amino or mercapto functional groups on at least some of the polymer molecules of the concentrate, said concentrate having a degree of functionality of from about 0.2 to about 2 mole percent, said concentrate having a viscosity of from about 50 to about 500 centistokes; and (b) a nonfunctional organosiloxane polymer diluent, said diluent having a viscosity of from about 100 to about 2,000 centistokes; said mixture having a degree of functionality of from about 0.05 to about 0.21 mole percent, wherein the mixture has a viscosity of from about 100 to about 1,000 centistokes, and wherein the ratio by weight of concentrate to diluent is from about 1:2 to about 1:30.

Specific embodiments of the invention will now be described in detail.
These examples are intended to be illustrative, and the invention is not limited to the materials, conditions, or process parameters set forth in these embodiments.
All parts and percentages are by weight unless otherwise indicated.

Release Life Testing: The described fusing release agents were evaluated on a three inch bench web fixture, the web continuously running at 20 centimeters per second.
The fuser roll coating comprised 1.5 millimeters of a thermally conductive silicone rubber with a release overcoat of 0.050 millimeter Viton GF cured with the E. I. DuPont de Nemours and Co.
VC-50 curing system.
The Viton GF layer contained no heavy metals, heavy metal oxides, or other metal compounds.
The fuser roll was 50 millimeters in diameter and was operated at 20 centimeters per second surface speed and at a run temperature of 360 (degree) F., which is 30 (degree) F. above the temperature at which image fix becomes acceptable.
A polyester toner was used for the image, and the image coverage was 50 percent.
The amount of toner as the image on the paper carrier was 1.0 milligrams per square centimeter.
The toner contained the proper amount of Aerosil (obtained from Cabot Corp.) to promote toner flow and a charge control agent to provide the necessary triboelectric charging characteristics for toner development.
Failure, in this instance, hot offset, occurred when part of the toner image became attached to the fuser roll and was then transferred to the paper on the next revolution of the fuser roll.
For the tests described herein, 500,000 prints was considered to be an acceptable release life.

Sample Generation: A Xerox.RTM. 5775 fuser roll was hand rubbed with oil soaked in a paper towel, and the oil rate on the first copy was typically from about 10 to about 20 milligrams (1 milligram=1 microliter) per copy.
Without further oil addition, the oil rate dropped on successive copies.
Copies were selected with the desired oil rate of 3 to 5 milligrams per copy.
There were no toner images on all of the peel force test samples.
The paper used was Xerox.RTM. Image Series LX and peel force measurements were performed on the felt side of the paper.

Oil-On-Copy: Since the pressure roll was engaged part of the time to help distribute the oil on the fuser roll, the pressure roll became coated with oil.
In addition, the inter-document gap also allowed oil transfer between the fuser roll and the pressure roll.
The amount of oil transferred from the pressure roll to the copy was unknown but could be significant, especially in the first few copies.
To eliminate this ambiguity, double sheets of paper were used in all samples generated for adhesion measurements, with the back sheet discarded.
Thus, the oil measured subsequently by solvent extraction came only from the front side of the copy.
The oil rates reported here are scaled to 8.5 inch by 11 inch size paper.

Adhesive: For the peel force measurements a 3M.RTM. -658 adhesive tape was used.
This 1 inch wide paper tape had the same adhesive as that coated on 3M Post-it.RTM. notes.
About 3.5 inches was used for each measurement, thereby increasing significantly the peel length and accuracy of the peel force measurement by averaging the peel force.

Adhesion Process: The adhesion developed was very sensitive to the force applied in bringing the adhesive and paper together.
To minimize any random error in this sensitive factor, a rubber coated steel roller that complied with the Pressure Sensitive Tape Council test procedure PSTC-1 for adhesive tapes, was employed.

Peel Force Measurement: Peel force measurements were performed with the Slip/Peel Tester model 3M90 made by Instrumentors, Inc.
According to the manufacturer, the strain gauge was accurate to 1 gram of force.
The instantaneous peel force was printed on a chart recorder for visual averaging over the test duration.
The peel angle was 180 (degree) with respect to the paper surface.
For consistent results, the adhesive was applied 5 minutes after print generation and peel force measurements made 5 minutes later.
For reference, the peel force required to separate the adhesive from Xerox.RTM. Image Series LX paper without any applied oil was measured to be about 124 grams per centimeter.

The following examples are tests of various types of amino functional silicone oil release agents with differing viscosities or a mixture of viscosities used in the above experiments.
All fluids were obtained from Dow Corning Corporation.
description.heading: EXAMPLE I
description.p: 500 centiStoke Nonfunctional Silicone Oil

A 500 centiStoke nonfunctional silicone fluid, with an oil application rate of 5 milligrams per print, produced hot offset after only some tens of prints, because of the absence of amine groups to bond to the Viton.RTM. surface.
Paper coated with this oil by the above described procedure at application rates of 3 and 5 milligrams per print demonstrated peel force values of 52 and 38 grams per centimeter, respectively, when subjected to the peel force test described above.
description.heading: EXAMPLE II
description.p: 350 centiStoke Amino Functional Silicone Oil

A 350 centiStoke amino functional silicone oil containing 0.6 mole percent pendant propylamine groups (concentrate) was blended with 350 centiStoke nonfunctional silicone oil (diluent) at a ratio by weight of 1 part amine-functional fluid to 3.6 parts nonfunctional fluid to produce a fluid containing 0.13 mole percent amine groups.
An amino oil mixture made according to this procedure, when utilized in the above described test with an oil application rate of 5 milligrams per print, yielded no hot offset after 500,000 prints, at which time point testing was suspended.
Paper coated with this oil, by the above-described procedure at application rates of 3 and 5 milligrams per print, demonstrated peel force values of 12 and 8 grams per centimeter, respectively, when subjected to the peel force test described above.
These peel force values are unacceptably low.
description.heading: EXAMPLE III
description.p: 100 centiStoke Amino Functional Silicone Oil

A 100 centiStoke amino functional silicone oil containing 0.6 mole percent pendant propylamine groups (concentrate) was blended with 100 centiStoke nonfunctional silicone oil (diluent) at a ratio by weight of 1 part amine-functional fluid to 3.6 parts nonfunctional fluid to produce a fluid containing 0.13 mole percent amine groups.
An amino oil mixture made according to this procedure, when utilized in the above described test with an oil application rate of 3 milligrams per print, produced hot offset failure at 200,000 prints.
This fuser lifetime is unacceptably low.
Paper coated with this oil by the above-described procedure at application rates of 3 and 5 milligrams per print demonstrated peel force values of 26 and 16 grams per centimeter, respectively, when subjected to the peel force test described above.
These peel force values are significantly higher than those achieved from the 350 centiStoke fluid of Example I. Release life, however, was considerably reduced.
description.heading: EXAMPLE IV
description.p: Mixed Viscosity Amino Functional Silicone Oil

A 100 centiStoke amino functional silicone oil containing 0.6 mole percent pendant propylamine groups (concentrate) was blended with 500 centiStoke nonfunctional silicone oil (diluent) at a ratio by weight of 1 part amine-functional fluid to 3.6 parts nonfunctional fluid to produce a 350 centiStoke fluid containing 0.13 mole percent amine groups.
An amino oil mixture made according to this procedure, when utilized in the above described test, with an oil application rate of 5 milligrams per print, produced no hot offset failure after 500,000 prints.
Paper coated with this oil by the above-described procedure at application rates of 3 and 5 milligrams per print demonstrated peel force values of 21 and 10 grams per centimeter, respectively, when subjected to the peel force test described above.
The peel force values obtained from this mixed viscosity oil were only slightly inferior to that of the 100 centiStoke fluid, which was applied at a lower oil rate.
Yet, the mixed viscosity fluid was able to achieve the required release life of 500,000 prints, a result similar to that obtained with the 350 centiStoke fluid of Example II and significantly better release life than the 100 centiStoke fluid of Example III.
Accordingly, the mixed viscosity fluid simultaneously achieved both acceptable Post-It.RTM. adhesion and acceptable fuser release life.
description.heading: EXAMPLE V
description.p:
The processes of Examples I through IV are repeated except that a mercapto functional polysiloxane oil is substituted for the amino functional polysiloxane oil.
It is believed that improved adhesion of Post-It.RTM. notes and acceptable fuser release life will be observed.

Other embodiments and modifications of the present invention may occur to those of ordinary skill in the art subsequent to a review of the information presented herein; these embodiments and modifications, as well as equivalents thereof, are also included within the scope of this invention.

claim.claim-text: What is claimed is:

A fuser member comprising a substrate, a layer thereover comprising a polymer, and, on the polymeric layer, a coating of a release agent comprising a mixture of (a) an organosiloxane polymer concentrate containing amino-substituted or mercapto-substituted organosiloxane polymers, wherein there are amino or mercapto functional groups on at least some of the polymer molecules of the concentrate, said concentrate having a degree of functionality of from about 0.2 to about 5 mole percent, said concentrate having a viscosity of from about 50 to about 500 centistokes;
and (b) a nonfunctional organosiloxane polymer diluent, said diluent having a viscosity of from about 100 to about 2,000 centistokes;

said mixture having a degree of functionality of from about 0.05 to about 0.4 mole percent, wherein the mixture has a viscosity of from about 100 to about 1,000 centistokes, and wherein the ratio by weight of concentrate to diluent is from about 1:2 to about 1:30.
2. A fuser member according to claim 1 wherein the mixture has a viscosity of from about 400 to about 800 centistokes.
3. A fuser member according to claim 1 wherein the mixture contains amino-functional organosiloxane polymers and has a degree of amino functionality of from about 0.05 to about 0.2 mole percent.
4. A fuser member according to claim 1 wherein the mixture contains amino-functional organosiloxane polymers and has a degree of amino functionality of from about 0.06 to about 0.12 mole percent.
5. A fuser member according to claim 1 wherein the mixture contains mercapto-functional organosiloxane polymers and has a degree of mercapto functionality of from about 0.1 to about 0.4 mole percent.

6. A fuser member according to claim 1 wherein the mixture contains mercapto-functional organosiloxane polymers and has a degree of mercapto functionality of from about 0.15 to about 0.3 mole percent.
7. A fuser member according to claim 1 wherein the amino-substituted or mercapto-substituted organosiloxane polymer is of the formula (Chemical Structure image '12' not included in text)

wherein G is --NHR11, or --SH, each of R1, R2, R3, R4, R5, R6, R7, R8, and R9, independently of the others, are alkyl groups or arylalkyl groups, R10 is an alkyl group or an arylalkyl group, R11 is a hydrogen atom, an alkyl group, or an arylalkyl group, and n and p are each integers representing the number of repeat monomer units.
8. A fuser member according to claim 1 wherein the nonfunctional organosiloxane polymer is of the formula (Chemical Structure image '13' not included in text)

wherein each of R1, R2, R3, R4, R5, R6, R7, and R8, independently of the others, is an alkyl group, an aryl group, or an arylalkyl group, and n is an integer representing the number of repeat monomer units.
9. A fuser member according to claim 1 wherein the nonfunctional organosiloxane polymer component of the release agent has a weight average molecular weight of from about 5,000 to about 50,000.
10. A fuser member according to claim 1 wherein the diluent component of the release agent has a viscosity of from about 500 to about 1,000 centistokes.
11. A fuser member according to claim 1 wherein the concentrate contains amino-functional organosiloxane polymers and has a degree of amino functionality of from about 0.2 to about 2 mole percent.
12. A fuser member according to claim 1 wherein the concentrate contains amino-functional organosiloxane polymers and has a degree of amino functionality of from about 0.5 to about 1 mole percent.

13. A fuser member according to claim 1 wherein the concentrate contains mercapto-functional organosiloxane polymers and has a degree of mercapto functionality of from about 0.5 to about 5 mole percent.

14. A fuser member according to claim 1 wherein the concentrate contains mercapto-functional organosiloxane polymers and has a degree of mercapto functionality of from about 1 to about 3 mole percent.

15. A fuser member according to claim 1 wherein the amino-substituted or mercapto-substituted organosiloxane polymer component of the release agent has a weight average molecular weight of from about 4,000 to about 20,000.
16. A fuser member according to claim 1 wherein the concentrate component of the release agent has a viscosity of from about 300 to about 400 centistokes.
17. A fuser member according to claim 1 wherein the ratio by weight of concentrate to the diluent is from about 1:3 to about 1:10.
18. A fuser member according to claim 1 wherein the polymer in the layer overlying the substrate is a fluoropolymer.
19. A process which comprises (i) generating an electrostatic latent image on an imaging member;
(ii) developing the latent image by contacting the imaging member with a developer;
(iii) transferring the developed image to a copy substrate;
and (iv) affixing the developed image to the copy substrate by contacting the developed image with a fuser member according to claim 1.
20. A process according to claim 19 wherein the copy substrate is paper.
21. An image forming apparatus for forming images on a recording medium which comprises:
(i) a charge-retentive surface capable of receiving an electrostatic latent image thereon;
(ii) a development assembly to apply toner to the charge-retentive surface, thereby developing the electrostatic latent image to form a developed image on the charge retentive surface;
(iii) a transfer assembly to transfer the developed image from the charge retentive surface to a copy substrate;
and (iv) a fixing assembly to fuse toner images to a surface of the copy substrate, wherein the fixing assembly includes a fuser member according to claim 1.
22. A process for improving adhesion to a fused print substrate and for improving fuser oil release life which comprises (i) generating an electrostatic latent image on an imaging member;
(ii) developing the latent image by contacting the imaging member with a developer;
(iii) transferring the developed image to a copy substrate;

and (iv) affixing the developed image to the copy substrate by contacting the developed image with a fuser member comprising a substrate, a layer thereover comprising a polymer, and, on the polymeric layer, a coating of a release agent comprising a mixture of (a) an organosiloxane polymer concentrate containing amino-substituted or mercapto-substituted organosiloxane polymers, wherein there are amino or mercapto functional groups on at least some of the polymer molecules of the concentrate, said concentrate having a degree of functionality of from about 0.2 to about 5 mole percent, said concentrate having a viscosity of from about 50 to about 500 centistokes;
and (b) a nonfunctional organosiloxane polymer diluent, said diluent having a viscosity of from about 100 to about 2,000 centistokes;

said mixture having a degree of functionality of from about 0.05 to about 0.4 mole percent, wherein the mixture has a viscosity of from about 100 to about 1,000 centistokes, and wherein the ratio by weight of concentrate to diluent is from about 1:2 to about 1:30.

23. A process for simultaneously obtaining acceptable adhesion to a fused print substrate and obtaining acceptable fuser oil release life which comprises (i) generating an electrostatic latent image on an imaging member, (ii) developing the latent image by contacting the imaging member with a developer;
(iii) transferring the developed image to a copy substrate;

and (iv) affixing the developed image to the copy substrate by contacting the developed image with a fuser member comprising a substrate, a layer thereover comprising a polymer, and, on the polymeric layer, a coating of a release agent comprising a mixture of (a) an organosiloxane polymer concentrate containing amino-substituted or mercapto-substituted organosiloxane polymers, wherein there are amino or mercapto functional groups on at least some of the polymer molecules of the concentrate, said concentrate having a degree of functionality of from about 0.2 to about 5 mole percent, said concentrate having a viscosity of from about 50 to about 500 centistokes;
and (b) a nonfunctional organosiloxane polymer diluent, said diluent having a viscosity of from about 100 to about 2,000 centistokes;

said mixture having a degree of functionality of from about 0.05 to about 0.4 mole percent, wherein the mixture has a viscosity of from about 100 to about 1,000 centistokes, and wherein the ratio by weight of concentrate to diluent is from about 1:2 to about 1:30.
